<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_condition_wait:
```c
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_condition_wait:
struct metal_condition {
	atomic_uintptr_t mptr; /**< mutex pointer.
				 * The condition variable is attached to
				 * this mutex when it is waiting.
				 * It is also used to check correctness
				 * in case there are multiple waiters.
				 */
	atomic_int waiters;    /**< number of waiters. */
	atomic_int wakeups;    /**< number of wakeups. */
}
...
typedef struct {
	atomic_int v;
} metal_mutex_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the pointer &cv->waiters is passed to atomic_fetch_sub to modify the atomic_int. Rule 8.13 recommends const-qualifying pointers when they are not used to modify the pointed-to object; here the object is intentionally modified, so it must not be const-qualified.
